characters: A DARK FIGURE COMING THROUGH THE WINDOW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark clouds drift across the moon. Here on Earth, in the village of Hannibal, a brisk wind stirs the treetops, @riving dead leaves down dark, empty streets. It's October, 1845, almost Halloween, and if this is a dress rehearsal for that night of spooky pleasure, then Halloween is sure to be a smash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A black cat darts across our path and runs up the side of a tree. —We PUSH IN on-the tree. THUNDER rumbles. Lightning flashes, illuminating a boy's name carved into the trunk of the tree: *TOM SAWYER." A DARK FIGURE stalks past the tree. We PAN it down the street toward a grim building whose overhanging sign, shaped like a coffin, reads: "DR. J.R. ROBINSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flickering candlelight illuminates a gruesome scene. The corpse of an elderly man is laid out on a slab. The man is dressed in a dark suit. His face is rouged and powdered, his eyes are closed and his hands have been folded across a Bible resting on his chest. Hovering over him, vuiture-like, is DOC ROBINSON, Hannibal's only undertaker, a man as gaunt and cadaverous as any body he has ever embalmed. At the moment, Doc is trying to create the proper look of contentment on the corpse's face, using his fingers to prod the pliable face muscles into a heavenly smile. But he can't get it right.

dialogues.speaker: DOC ROBINSON
dialogues.text: {under his breath; grumbling) Smile, damn you. That's when the door swings open, letting in a gust of wind. Some of the candles flicker and blow out, giving the room a darker, more macabre ambiance -- appropriate lighting for the entrance of INJUN JOE.  2 Dee Robinson turns and glares at the intruder -- a tall half-breed with long black hair, penetrating eyes and sharp, Satanic features. He is the dark figure we saw moments ago, Hannibal's scourge, Injun Joe.

dialogues.speaker: DOC ROBINSON
dialogues.text: (continuing) Shut the door... Injun Joe's eyes narrow to mean slits. He doesn't like being ordered about. ‘But he closes the door and comes into the room.

dialogues.speaker: INJUN JOE
dialogues.text: (ill-tempered) What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: DOC ROBINSON
dialogues.text: I have a job for you.

dialogues.speaker: INJUN JOE
dialogues.text: What kind of job?

dialogues.speaker: DOC ROBINSON
dialogues.text: It's heavy work, we'll need another man... Injun Joe peers through Doc -- knows he's up to no good..

dialogues.speaker: INJUN JOE
dialogues.text: When do you want it done?

dialogues.speaker: DOC ROBINSON
dialogues.text: Tomorrow night... “INJON JOE Where?

dialogues.speaker: DOC ROBINSON
dialogues.text: The graveyard. Injun Joe raises and eyebrow...

dialogues.speaker: DOC ROBINSON
dialogues.text: (continuing) Unless you're afraid. {turns back to his work) The job pays two dollars. Take it or leave it... Injun Joe casually pulls a silver knife from inside his coat...

dialogues.speaker: INJUN JOE
dialogues.text: I'll take it. (a beat) But the job pays three dollars

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Injun Joe very delicately wipes the blade of his kn en Doc Robinson's chest, where his heart should be.

dialogues.speaker: INJUN JOE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Unless you think I deserve more. pdoc ROBINSON (terrified) No, no. Three dollars sounds fair. Injun Joe winks at Doc Robinson, then turns and strides out the door, letting it slam behind him. The resulting wind blows out the remaining candles. Doc Robinson is left trembling in the darkness. Cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EELLS begin to toll the hour of midnight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on a clock sitting on a night stand between two beds. As the minute hand moves to midnight, we hear covers RUSTLING and PAN over to TOM SAWYER as he sits up in bed, eyes flashing with excitement. Tom throws off his covers to reveal that he's completely dressed and ready for action. Tom swings out of bed, a rugged, good-looking kid of twelve. He shoots a look at his cousin SIDNEY who occupies the other bed, snoring peacefully. Sid is a year younger than Tom and his opposite in every way. Outwardly a model boy, Sid is actually a mean, sneaky, little tattletale. Tom, on the other hand, is a pure force of unbridled nature, born for trouble and adventure. He goes to the window, raises it and is halfway out when he hears: siID And where do you think you're going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom turns. Sid is sitting up in bed, smiling with smus superiority, having caught Tom in the act of sneaxing ovr But Tom doesn't seem worried.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Go back to sleep, Sid. I'm just runnin' away from home.

dialogues.speaker: SID
dialogues.text: Again?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: This time for good. (can't contain his excitement) Me and Joe Harper and Ben Rogers is goin' to New Orleans to be steamboat men.

dialogues.speaker: SID
dialogues.text: Not if I tell Aunt Polly! Sid is about to open his mouth and shout "Aunt Polly!" when Tom pounces on him and clamps a hand over his mouth,

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I had a feelin' you was gonna be your usual nasty self so I rigged up a little surprise. As Sid struggles, Tom reaches under the bed, pulling up handfuls of rope that he has already secured to the bed frame. As Sid thrashes, Tom ties him to the bed and shoves a dirty sock in his mouth to stifle his cries.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: {continuing) And just so you won't be lonely... Tom reaches under the bed and brings up a topless glass jar which he balances on Sid's heaving chest. Sid's eyes cross and bug out when he sees what's in the jar -- a big black spider! Sid is terrified of spiders. He freezes.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (continuing) That's a black widow. Sid -- the most poisonous spider in the whole world. You knock over that jar and she's gonna be mad. Sid doesn't dare move. Tom saunters to the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: d4eontinuing! ‘Course, I could be wrong Te might just be a harmless fruit spider. But there's only one way to find out... And with a grin, Tom is gone out the window. Sid stares at the spider in the jar, trying to keep completely still hk big drop of sweat runs down his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom shimmies down the drainpipe and is gone into the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom runs for all he's worth, heart soaring with boyish excitement. Right on cue, JOE HARPER hops over a fence and joins him. A moment later, BEN ROGERS comes through a gate and the three boys race through the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shadows of Tom, Joe and Ben flash across the dark storefronts, The boys zoom around a corner and put on the brakes so they don't collide with MUFF POTTER, the town drunk who is ambling along. Muff is a friendly good- hearted fellow, a buddy to all the boys in Hannibal.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Hey, Muff!

dialogues.speaker: MUFF
dialogues.text: Howdy, boys. Where ya headed this time of night?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: We're runnin' away from home.

dialogues.speaker: MUFF
dialogues.text: {good-naturedly) Oh, I used to do that all the time -- 'til home ran away from me. Came back one day and everybody was gone...

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Where'd they go?

dialogues.speaker: MUFF
dialogues.text: (chuckles) As far away as they could.  Joe and Ben look at bit nonplussed. Is this a cautionary tale Mufi'’s telling?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: {to the boys) Come on

dialogues.speaker: MUFF
dialogues.text: Don't let me stop you. Tom, Joe and Ben move off. Muff calls after them...

dialogues.speaker: MUTF
dialogues.text: (continuing) Hey! When ya comin' back?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: {over his . shoulder; as he runs) Never! The boys are out of sight. Muff grins and takes a hit from his jug. This isn't the first time the boys have run away.

dialogues.speaker: MUFF
dialogues.text: Never, huh? {chuckles; with confidence) See ya tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom, Joe and Ben clamber down a steep wooded bank, thrashing their way through thick bushes and trees, slipping and sliding, overcome with excitement. Shortly, they reach their own secret harbor where a log raft is anchored in the moonlight. Tom, Joe and Ben board the raft and scramble about making her "seaworthy." Within seconds the anchor is raised and all lines are cast off. Wind takes hold of the bed-sheet sail and suddenly the raft is in motion. The strong current carries it downstream. Joe mans the rudder.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Hannibal! Tom notices that his shipmates are gazing back at the dow with a certain melancholy.  at

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Jeontinuing) Don't tell me you're gett homesick already.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: No, Tom. It's just... well, ain't you gonna miss your family?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think steamboat men got families? Heck, that's the main reason we're runnin’ away, ain't it? So's we can be free to do what we want -- when we want ~~ and not have to answer -— to nobody... ~ “{snorts) Families. (goading them) But if you boys want to go home...

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: No, Tom. We made a pact.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Last chance. Once we hit the Muddy, there's no turning back. Joe and Ben steel their courage.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: No, Tom. We're with ya. All the way. Tom neds, proud of his crew.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Then it's full speed ahead. They turn their backs to Hannibal as the raft carries the toward the big river.

dialogues.speaker: RIVER JUNCTION
dialogues.text: Where Murrell's Creek meets the Mississippi. From a HIGH ANGLE, we see Tom's "ship" as it joins the Big Muddy and Sails downstream. The river is dark and treacherous but this is an exciting moment for Tom and his shipmates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Water comes crashing over the bow, sprayins the boys. They love it. Riding the Mississippi is the 1640's equivalent of a roller coaster.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: We made the Muddy, boys! Next stop -- New Orleans! Nothin’ can stop us now! That's when a dark shape looms in their path -- a sandbs:

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (continuing) Mister Harper -- hard to port! Too late. The little raft smashes into the -sandbar -and upends itself. Tom, Joe and Ben are picked up and tossed into the water. Tom hits his head on the edge of the raft and is stunned. The current yanks him down. Darkness. Confusion. Joe and Ben cling to the sandbar for dear life. uttering, gasping for breath, they look around to locate their captain and see Tom being swept downriver.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (terrified) Tom! But Tom hears nothing. He is unconscious, going under, _ coming up, at the mercy of the powerful current.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNRIVER
dialogues.text: A fallen elm overhangs the Mississippi, its trunk extending above the rising water. Tom is swept along. As he passes under the tree, a FIGURE appears out of nowhere, dressed in rags and tatters. Quick as lightning, the Figure scrambles out to the end o the tree and dives in after Tom.

dialogues.speaker: JOE AND BEN
dialogues.text: They gape in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: What was that?  ire)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pulled under. A hand grabs him from beh

dialogues.speaker: JOE AND BEN
dialogues.text: They make their way to shore and hurry downriver.

dialogues.speaker: RIVER BANK
dialogues.text: His limp body is carried to shore by the unseen Figure wh gently places him on the bank. Filthy hands turn Tom on his back and pump his chest. Tom suddenly comes to life. He sputters and coughs up a gallon of the Mississippi. His eyes flicker open.

dialogues.speaker: LOOKING UP
dialogues.text: A strange face swings INTO FOCUS above him, framed agains the night sky. The eyes flash, bright blue. Then, the face is gone.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: He sits up as Joe and Ben arrive.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You all right, Tom?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: ‘Course I'm all right.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: If it hadn't been for that... (shares a look with Joe) ... whatever it was... you'd have been a goner. A chill wind comes up, RUSTLING the tree tops, bringing the surrounding forest to life. It sounds like someone -- or some thing -- is coming. The boys leok at each other.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Town?

dialogues.speaker: JOE AND BEN
dialogues.text: (vigorous nods) Town!  10 The boys scramble to their feet and run like hell. As they disappear up the shore, we hear TWIGS SNAFPING. FOOTSTEPS approach. A tattered shoulder moves INTO FRAME and the back of a boy’s head. His hair is long and wild. It hangs to his shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun comes up, casting long shadows. We see the sleepy little village with the Mississippi running on one side, hills and dense forest on the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the shadow of a great pirate, fighting a cutlass duel with an invisible opponent. PULL BACK to reveal that it's Tom with a long stick, sword-fighting his way back home .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom shimmies up the drainpipe and climbs through the open window to his room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom looks around. No sign of Sid. As usual, Sid's bed is neatly made. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on Tom's AUNT POLLY, a handsome woman in her forties. She is seated at the breakfast table. WIDEN to include Sid and Tom's pretty sixteen-year-old COUSIN MARY All three are poker-faced, silently eating breakfast. Tom enters in clean clothes. Determined to play the innocent until accused, Tom seats himself and tucks a napkin into his shirt.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (cheerful) Mornin', everybody. What's for breakfast?

dialogues.speaker: AUNT POLLY
dialogues.text: You can start with this...  a ray Polly places a jar in front of Tom It contains the Spider.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Couldn't I just have some scrambled eggs instead? Polly takes Tom by the collar and pulls him out of his chaiz. She leads him out the back door.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT POLLY
dialogues.text: Tom, I've a mind to skin you alive. Sneaking out ‘til all hours, worrying a body to death... Mary frowns, sorry for Tom. Sid couldn't be happier. He smirks and heaps his plate with eggs and grits, then wolf them down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aunt Polly, still holding Tom by the collar, leads out on the back porch...

dialogues.speaker: AUNT POLLY
dialogues.text: Hand me that switch... Tom gets the switch from behind the door...

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (testing it in the air) ... Seems mighty weak, Aunt Polly. Must be all used up... Tom hands her the switch, locking her with a carefully composed look of anguish and contrition.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (continuing) I'll go and cut you a new one... He starts toward the birch tree but she stops him...

dialogues.speaker: AUNT POLLY
dialogues.text: (melting) Tom... Tom, what am I gonna do with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (feigning innocence} You mean before, or after my whippin', Aunt Polly?

dialogues.speaker: AUNT POLLY
dialogues.text: (sadly) I swore to your momma, my own Sister, on her death bed that I'd raise you proper.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: And you're sure doing that.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT POLLY
dialogues.text: (shakes her head) No, I know I'm not doing my @uty by you -- but I haven't got the heart to hit you.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Would it help if I just bent over, real quiet, and looked the other way?

dialogues.speaker: AUNT POLLY
dialogues.text: (in defeat) No, no, every time I hit you my old heart almost breaks. And every time I let you off my conscience hurts me just as bad...

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Yes'm. She puts down the switch.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT POLLY
dialogues.text: I suppose I'll just be obliged to make you work tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: AUNT POLLY
dialogues.text: Well, I've got to do something...

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Tomorrow's Saturday...

dialogues.speaker: AUNT POLLY
dialogues.text: (turning away) I've got to do some of my duty by you...  13 Aunt Polly goes into the house. Tom hesitates a moment, then grabs up the switch and chases after her...

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Aunt Polly...! Wait! I'll take the whippin'! EXT. POLLY'S HOUSE - DAY_. Tom steps through the gate, carrying a bucket of whitewas and a long-handled brush. He surveys the fence that borders the yard -- thirty yards long, nine feet high. He’ll be an old man before he finishes the job. A small black kid named JEB comes around the corner, - carrying an empty bucket.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Hello, Jeb, ol' buddy.

dialogues.speaker: JEB
dialogues.text: (wary) Hello, Tom.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Tell ya what. I'll go to the pump for you if you'll do some paintin'.

dialogues.speaker: JEB
dialogues.text: Can't do it, Tom. Your Aunt Polly said she'd lay me low if I let you talk me into paintin'’.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: You ain't afraid of her, are you?

dialogues.speaker: JEB
dialogues.text: (nods a terrified *yes") Goodbye, Tom. Jeb walks off. Tom thinks fast.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I'll show you my bloody toe! Jeb stops in his tracks. He turns around. Tom removes his left boot and lifts his foot. His big toe is wrapped in a bandage. Tom wiggles it seductively. Jeb is greatly tempted but thinks of Aunt Polly. He hurries on his way. Tom goes for the throat:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) It's got pus. Jeb stops. His face is in turmoil. Tom delivers the coz d= grace:

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (continuing) Yellow -- dripping -- pus. That does it. Jeb spins around.

dialogues.speaker: JEB
dialogues.text: You got a deal! Jeb puts down the bucket and rushes over to Tom who start to unwrap his bandage. Jeb bends over to-get a tciose loo and -- WHAP! -- a broom swats him on the ass. Jeb lets out a yelp, garbs his bucket and high-tails it down the road. Tom looks up into the no-nonsense face of Aunt Polly. She points to the fence.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT POLLY
dialogues.text: No excuses! And returns to the house. Tom frowns. He laconically picks up the brush and is about to dip it in the whitewash when he hears one of the younger neighborhood boys, little BILLY NEWTON coming up the lane, whooping and clanging and pretending to be a steamboat. ee eee _ . A wicked smile spreads across Tom's face. He dips his brush in the whitewash bucket and begins painting the fence with great gusto. He whistles a happy tune. Billy Newton, completely baffled by Tom's behavior, cuts off hi steamboat imitation and comes over to watch.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: You feelin’ okay, Tom? Tom turns, pretending to be surprised.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Oh. Hi, Billy. I was having so much fun I didn't hear you comin'.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: (astounded) Fun?  uw

dialogues.speaker: TON
dialogues.text: Whitewashin' this here fence.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: That ain't fun. That's work.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: If it was work, would I be doin' it? Tom frowns at Billy and shakes his head as if he's just too young to understand. Tom resumes his painting and whistling...

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (continuing) ... Ain't every day a boy gets -a chance to whitewash a fence. Billy watches...

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Say, Tom...

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Hmm?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Let me paint a littie. He almost smiles.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) Aunt Polly's awful particular about this fence...

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Just a little...?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Billy, I'd like to -- but if I was to let you start paintin' and anything was to happen to this fence, I'd be in big trouble...

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I’11 be real careful... Tom continues painting...  16

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (slyly) . What'll you give me? cuT To:

dialogues.speaker: SEVERAL MINUTES LATER
dialogues.text: CAMERA IS CLOSE on a black cat's-eye marble held between two fingers. PULL BACK to reveal the fingers as Tom's. He sits under a tree among a pile of boy treasures -- a brass doorknob, tadpoles in a jar, candy, a kite, firecrackers etc. In the b.g., half a dozen small boys vigorously whitewash the fence. The job is almost done. Tom shines the cat's-eye on his pants leg and slips it in his pocket. Then he picks up one of his treasures -- a@ pook about Robin Hood and his Merry Men, complete with inspiring illustrations. Tom is deep in the book as Joe Harper and Ben Rogers come up Meadow Lane. They see Tom under the tree and approach.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (a trace of sarcasm) Well, if it ain't the two bravest steamboat men on the Mississippi.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: (contrite) Lookit, Tom, we're awful sorry about last night not workin’ out.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: We could build another boat... Tom dismisses the idea. He's got a new idea.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Forget it. Anybody can be a steamboat man these days. But outlaws... that's somethin’ else.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (intrigued) Outlaws? Tom shows them the pictures in the book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a st

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Sure. Like Robin Hood and his Merry Men. All we need is the woods and some bows and arrows. We'll rob from the rich and give to the poor! On his excited look, we... cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A horse and carriage travel down a tree-lined lane on the outskirts of Hannibal. The buggy's driver is a prosperous iooking gentleman in his forties, HENRY THATCHER. On the seat beside himis his-beautiful-tweive-year old daughter; BECKY.

dialogues.speaker: THATCHER
dialogues.text: Hannibal's a wonderful place, Becky. It's not exactly St. Louis but I know you're going to like it.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: IT hope so. What are the children like? Before he can reply, Thatcher is forced to rein in the horses and stop. A small tree lies across the road, blocking transit.

dialogues.speaker: THATCHER
dialogues.text: What the... As if on cue, three boys scramble out of the greenery and position themselves in front of the carriage. Tom. Joe. Ben. All wielding crude homemade bows and arrows and wearing frond-leaf caps. Tom swaggers forward, playing Robin Hood to the hilt.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Throw down your valuables or feel the tip of Robin Hood's black arrow! Thatcher and Becky stare at the three "outlaws." It's all Thatcher can do to keep from laughing. Even Becky hides a smile. Thatcher decides to play along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: eE mn

dialogues.speaker: THATCHER
dialogues.text: i'm afraid the only thing I have of value is my daughter Rebecca... 0 7 rc) Tom Sawyer sees Becky Thatcher for the first tim heart jumps into his throat.

dialogues.speaker: THATCHER
dialogues.text: ' (continuing) ... and I'd sooner take one of your arrows in the heart than hand over such a treasure. With great effort, Tom swallows his heart and finds his voice. He squeaks something, tries again. It helps if he doesn't look at Becky. But that's impossible.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Well... uh... don't you have a watch or something? Some ' money?

dialogues.speaker: ' THATCHER
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. They were stolen by bandits about a mile back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom is frustrated. He has to get something.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: ' Then I'll take that hat you're wearing.

dialogues.speaker: THATCHER
dialogues.text: It was a gift from Rebecca's i late mother.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: You intend to resist?

dialogues.speaker: THATCHER
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I must. You see, I'm the new Judge in these parts... Joe and Ben look at each other. The new Judge!

dialogues.speaker: THATCHER
dialogues.text: (continuing) ... and if folks heard that I let three highwaymen get the better of me... Thatcher reaches inside his coat pocket and takes out a big pistol. He raises it and cocks the trigger. Six eyeballs bug out in fear.  1g With a collective "Yah!" the three Merry Men drop their bows and arrows and haul-ass into the woods Just for effect, the Judge FIRES a shot in the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thatcher and Becky share a good lauch.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: Those are the silliest boys I've ever seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom, Joe and Ben run off in three different directions. We STAY with Tom who dodges trees, leaps over logs, stumbles and falls down. He goes to pick himself up wher. he is surprised to.see two filthy bare feet in front of him. Slowly, Tom looks up. fee : -—e

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looming above him is a startling apparition -- HUCK FINN. Huck is Tom's age but a little taller and more muscular. Dressed in rags and tatters, Huck exudes a dangerous, heroic quality -- like a juvenile Tarzan or a Peter Pan gone to seed. A long knife is stuck in his belt.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Huck...!

dialogues.speaker: HUCK
dialogues.text: (nods in recognition) .+. Tom Sawyer.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: {jumping up) You're back...

dialogues.speaker: HUCK
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) Just movin’ through, more or less. “TOM Well, where'd you go? Where you been?

dialogues.speaker: HUCK
dialogues.text: (snide) You mean after your good townfolk ran me out? Tom nods...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: {continuing) Lots of places, no place in particular -- upriver, downriver.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (realizing) You're the one that pulled me out last night. Huck shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: HUCK
dialogues.text: I felt like a swim. (motioning) J Come on, I'll show you my camp... oe FOLLOW as Huck leads Tom through a wall of dense vegetation ... They emerge in a hidden glade... . Tom looks around. The glade has been transformed into an outdoor living room. A hammock hangs between two trees. Cast-off furniture has been set about giving the place a lived-in homey feel.
